result.body:
Evelyn Belle Johnson, born Evelyn Belle Lewis, was an African American student at Miami University from 1931 to 1935. She was born April 17th, 1914 in Muncie, Indiana to parents Harry Lewis and Viola Herd Lewis. Evelyn and her family moved to Kenton, Ohio at an early age, where her father worked as a shoe shiner. She attended Kenton High School, serving on the student council and graduating in 1931.

Evelyn enrolled at Miami University that fall, pursuing a degree in education with an emphasis in English. During her time as a student, she was active in the Y.W.C.A. and held various leadership positions in the organization, including being elected to the cabinet and serving as religious council. Evelyn was a student athlete, playing for both the women’s field hockey team and women’s soccer team, as well as being a member of the Women’s Athletic Association. Though Miami did not have a chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha— the first intercollegiate, historically African American sorority— while she was a student, there was an Ivy Leaf Pledge Club on campus beginning in 1931, allowing Miami women interested in joining AKA to become candidates for initiation in surrounding undergraduate chapters. Many of these women, including Evelyn, were initiated into AKA through the nearby Omicron chapter at the University of Cincinnati. She and the other Miami AKAs were therefore considered “Stray Greeks”, as they belonged to a group of students whose fraternity or sorority were not represented on Miami’s campus. Miami would eventually charter its own chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha in 1977. Evelyn graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Education in the spring of 1935.

After graduation, Evelyn began working for the office of the Ohio Secretary of State in Columbus. It was during her time in Columbus that she met her future husband, Kenneth L. Johnson, who had recently graduated from Wilberforce University— a historically African American university in Xenia, Ohio and the first in the nation to be Black-owned and operated— and was working for the Columbus Y.M.C.A. as a program manager. Evelyn moved to Xenia to work as a secretary for Wilberforce before she and Kenneth wed in 1941. Following Kenneth’s service in Europe during World War II, the couple moved to Pine Bluff, Arkansas, where Kenneth began working at the historically black university Arkansas AM&N College (now University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff) as the Director of Athletics and Chairman of the Department of Health, Physical Education and Recreation. Evelyn would join the faculty a few years later working in the English department. She earned her Masters of English from Boston University and continued working for Arkansas AM&N until she retired in 1984. Kenneth and Evelyn had two children together, Kenneth Jr. and Marilyn Elaine.

A member of the National Association of University Women, the Altar of Rosary Society of St. Peter Catholic Church, and the Board of Trustees of the Arts and Sciences Center for Southeast Arkansas, Evelyn continued to serve the Pine Bluff community through her civic involvement throughout her life. She also remained active in Alpha Kappa Alpha— in 1947, she, along with a group of local AKA women, got together to begin organizing the charter of a graduate chapter in Pine Bluff. The Delta Omega Omega chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha was chartered in the fall of 1948 with Evelyn as a founding member. She earned the distinction of Diamond Soror in 2006, a title given to individuals who have been an active member of AKA for seventy five years.
 
Evelyn passed away on December 9th, 2011 at the age of ninety-seven. At the time of her death, she had been a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha for eighty years.

result.body:
Atsushi “Herbert” Saito was a Japanese American student who attended Miami University from 1940 to 1943. Born on April 21st, 1921 in Kapehu, Hawaii to parents Shinichi Saito and Onao Kurisu Saito, he grew up in North Hilo, Hawaii where both of his parents worked at a sugar cane plantation. Saito graduated from Hilo High School in 1939, spending a year working in the county clerk’s office before enrolling at Miami as a Liberal Arts major on a pre-law track in the fall of 1940.

During his time at Miami, Herbert was involved in a number of student organizations. He served as president of the Cosmopolitan Club— an international club that welcomed students of diverse backgrounds— and was a member of the Speakers Bureau, the Association of Miami Independents, Tau Kappa Alpha fraternity, and Les Politiques, a club for those interested in political science. Selected to participate in the Fisk Public Speaking Contest all three years he attended Miami, he placed third his freshman and sophomore years and second his senior year. Several of his speeches focused on his experiences growing up in the then-Hawaii Territory— in addition to public speaking opportunities, he also vocalized his support for Hawaiian statehood in publications like *The Miami Student*. When U.S. involvement in World War II created an increased need for Japanese translators, Saito volunteered to teach a non-credit Japanese course to assist his peers in learning the language. He taught the course for two years. He was one of many Miami students during the war years who, as part of a larger project conducted by history professor Dr. William E. Smith, documented both their daily campus lives and perceptions of the war through diary entries. Herbert graduated in the spring of 1943 and enlisted in the military that July, where he served as a linguist in the U.S. Army Air Force.

Following his return from war, Saito began teaching back home on Hilo, first at Kohala High School and then at Konawaena High School, where he would eventually retire from. An English teacher, he served as an advisor to a number of different extracurricular clubs, including the Kona Junior Rifle Club and the Kona Junior Young Buddhist Association. He married Ayoka “Ethel” Imai in 1950— the couple had three daughters together, Gloria, Darlene, and Jeanne. Herbert remained active in the Hilo community throughout his life, serving as a Sunday school teacher at his Honwanji Buddhist temple, commander of Post 20 of the American Legion, and secretary for the Kona Invitational Softball League.

Herbert Saito passed away on June 12th, 1993 at the age of seventy-two.

result.body:
William Frederick Hargraves made Miami history in 1925 when he and Eleanor Reece became the first two African American students to earn a four-year bachelor’s degree from the university. He was born on February 5th, 1902 to parents Hammond Arthur Hargraves and Anna Langford Hargraves in Barnesville, Ohio, where Hammond worked as a hotel porter. William attended grade school in Gila, Arizona before the family moved to Oxford, Ohio in 1911, where both of William’s parents began working for the university— Anna as a cook and Hammond as a janitor. After graduating from Oxford High School, he enrolled at Miami in the fall of 1921, pursuing a Bachelor of Arts degree.
 
William was the first of his three siblings to attend the university. His brother, Langford, enrolled at Miami in 1924, finishing his degree at Wilberforce University— a historically African American university in Xenia, Ohio and the first in the nation to be Black-owned and operated— in 1932. His sister, Edythe, graduated from Miami with an education degree in 1943. Both of his siblings went on to have careers at Miami— Langford worked as a pool technician in the campus athletic facilities, while Edythe worked as a secretary in the Department of Home Economics and Division of Secondary Education until her passing in 1947. According to family accounts, she was the first African-American to be professionally hired by the university. William graduated from Miami in the spring of 1925, demonstrating great academic success in the face of adversity and paving the way for generations of Black Miami students to come.

In 1929, Hargraves began his career as a social studies teacher at the Lincoln-Grant School in Covington, Kentucky, a segregated public K-12 school building for African American students consisting of both an elementary school (Lincoln School) and high school (William Grant High School). During his first year living in Covington, he and another teacher stayed in the home of Lincoln-Grant’s principal, Henry R. Merry. William married Annie Leona Thomas, who also taught at the Lincoln-Grant School, in June of 1930 in Lorain, Ohio. The couple had two children together, William II and Beatrice. Hargraves earned his Master of Arts degree from Miami in 1936. While living in Oxford, he was a member of the Bethel A.M.E. Church— he transferred his membership to the St. James A.M.E. Church when he moved to Covington, where he served both as a trustee and as superintendent of their Sunday school.

William Hargraves I passed away on December 12th, 1953 at the age of fifty-one and is buried in Woodside Cemetery.

result.bio: Randi Thomas has been the Vice President of ASPIRE (advancing strategy, partnerships, institutional relations, and economy) at Miami University since 2020. A Miami alumnus, he obtained a bachelor’s degree in Political Science and Speech Communication in 1988 and master’s degree in Speech Communication in 1990 before graduating from the Vanderbilt School of Law in 1993. Thomas returned to Miami in 1999 to serve as the Director of Institutional Relations and played an instrumental role in creating the Work+ program at Miami Regionals.

result.body:
Louise Clark McBain began her academic journey at Miami University in 1928, she graduated in 1932 with a BS in Education, and returned to complete a graduate degree in 1944. Born in Alabama in 1910, Louise and her family originally from Alabama moved to Lemon Township, just south of Middletown, Ohio during the 1920’s. Her father Bishop Clark, born in Alabama, was a rolling mill steel worker. The family’s movement to Ohio contributed to the Great Migration of African Americans from the south to industrial towns in the north seeking opportunity. Louise pursues her own path, following the movement of her family to Ohio, she decided to get a college education.

In 1928, Black students were not allowed to live in the dorms. Louise lived with African American families during her time as a student at Miami. She lived with the “vegetable lady” from the girls' dining hall who offered her twenty five cents an hour for up to five hours a week to pare vegetables. This is how Louise earned her spending money. When Louise lived with Mr. and Mrs. Byrd on Oak Street was still under the same rules as if she were a student living in the dorms. Before she could leave the house, she had to record where she was going and when she would return on a sign in sheet, however Louise shared that the girls usually wrote the library even when that was not where they were going. This sheet would be delivered to Dean Hamilton at the end of each week. The girls feared if they were ever late they would risk being kicked out of Miami. Louise and the other girls living with the Byrd’s paid the same room and board as the on campus students. These girls would stay there most of the year, only leaving for the summer and Christmas break. They stayed in Oxford for Thanksgiving, African American students would come together at someone's home and the parents would make dinner. Louise spent six weeks of her studies living away from Miami University to complete her student teaching. Miami spent one hundred dollars for African American students to complete their student teaching at Xenia, a Black highschool. She stayed here for six weeks to complete her student teaching requirement.

An exceptionally active participant during her time as a student, Louise was president of the Ivy League Club. She was a club member of the Y.W.C.A, which defined itself as united in the desire to realize a full and creative life through a growing knowledge of God. She was also a member of the Mathematics Club. Eva Clark Mitchell, the sister of Louise, claimed Louise was a mathematical and computer type, making it no surprise she ended up in the university's Mathematics Club. The Mathematics Club was open to all students and faculty who wanted to come together and consider mathematical topics outside of scheduled courses, twice a month.

Most importantly, she was a lifelong member of the first intercollegiate historically-African American sorority, founded in 1908,  Alpha Kappa Alpha (AKA). She remained dedicated to Alpha Kappa Alpha for the duration of her life. During much of her time at Miami she was a dedicated member to Miami University’s women's sports teams. Despite being nervous to try out for athletics due to fear of being left out, she decided to try out. She was a member of Varsity Soccer, Hockey, Volleyball, Basketball, Baseball, and Track during her four years at Miami. With each team a student made, they were awarded points to wear on the pocket of their sweater, she had 32. The goal was to gain enough points to earn an M, which she did.

After graduating from Miami University, Louise became a prominent educator and administrator. At Dayton’s Dunbar High School, a historically African American high school, she taught math for seventeen years. Louise shared that Miami recognized her as a good teacher and sent twelve white students to do student teaching in her classroom at Dunbar. Dr. Christofferson, her mentor, who had recommended her for student teaching suggested she return to Miami to complete her master’s degree. Her masters project was called, *What Are The Relationships, If Any, Between Social And Economic Backgrounds And School Achievement*. Her thesis professor was Dr. Edmiston. Her goal was to see if kids with the most money received the best grades; she tested this theory on one hundred and fifty ninth graders at Dayton Dunbar High School. After that, she served as Principal of Booker T. Washington School in Middletown. She taught math at MHS in her final years before retiring in 1980. She was a lifelong active member of Delta Kappa Gamma (KΣΔ), a professional educator organization for women founded in 1929, and remained an active member the rest of her life. Louise married Herbert McBain on December 20, 1941. Herbert was the maintenance superintendent of the grounds in Middletown Regional Hospital. They had one daughter named Zee Whitetaker, and two grandsons. On September 17, 1989 Louise passed away at the age of seventy nine after an extended battle with cancer. In 1989 Louise was honored by Miami University with the Bishop Medal, a recognition of her extraordinary career as a student and educator. The Bishop Medal, established in 1936, is given to individuals who have distinguished themselves in service to humanity. The Bishop Medal is named after Robert Hamilton Bishop, Miami’s first president. Louise Clark McBain embraced the life of being a Miami student and her long career in education meant she graced hundreds, perhaps thousands, of other students with her guidance and wisdom.

result.body:
When Myldred Boston sent out letters to multiple schools requesting information, Miami University was one of the first schools to reply. After visiting campus she was excited to start her education. When Myldred entered Miami University in 1945 she was the first in her family to attend college. She graduated in 1949 with a Bachelor of Arts in Sociology. Myldred was a great driving force for needed change, on campus and off. Through her bravery and refusal to accept unacceptable treatment, Myldred used her voice to instill change.
 
Myldred was one of the first two female African American students to live on campus. When Myldred arrived on Move in Day in 1945, she was very disappointed. The room she was assigned was not only in appalling conditions, it was in the basement, next to the furnace room. In a 2006 interview Myldred recalled, “ that wasn’t going to be where I would be living,”. Myldred invited the Dean of Women to see the dorm room herself. When she arrived, Myldred asked the Dean if she would live there, her response was no and Myldred said “and so was mine.” For the rest of her first year, Myldred lived with Mr. and Mrs. Jackson, an African American family living on Vine Street in Oxford. At the time many African American students lived with local African American families so they could attend the university.
 
Her sophomore year, Myldred lived at the Tallawanda Apartments. The transition back onto campus would prove to create new challenges for Myldred. Miami University reached out to the parents of the other students living at the Tallawanda Apartments to ask them if they knew an African American woman would be living on the first floor. All of the students living on the first floor with Myldred were women whose parents consented. Myldred recounted that she had met the women who would become her roommates in class and they got along. Myldred’s dorm included herself and five other women. The Tallawanda Apartment building housed two hundred women across three floors. Myldred proved that the dorms could successfully integrate.
 
On campus and uptown proved to be problematic for the African American community. Myldred recalled, “The people in the town who wanted to buy sandwiches would be served from the rear of that establishment,” she said. “You’d have to go to the back of the establishment and get your brown paper bag … and I just couldn’t do that.”. The racial discrimination Myldred experienced inspired her to join the Campus Interracial Club where she held the position of corresponding secretary. The club did not feel welcomed on campus so instead the students sought off campus options for club meetings and social events. Myldred shared that, “the people in the town opened their homes to us so I have a strong affinity for them”. The Campus Interracial Club provided a social space for African American students to get the support they needed and feel heard. During Myldred’s time as a student, she saw change in the uptown restaurants.  Myldred said, “Those who were serving us at first didn’t serve us,” she said. “But we sat and sat, and we changed positions and others would come and sit, and all of a sudden at some point in time, we could walk in and be seated and were served.”

After graduating from Miami University in 1949, Myldred completed a Masters of Library and Information Science from Case Western Reserve University in 1957. For ten years, Myldred taught elementary school in Cleveland, Ohio. She shifted careers when she started working in real estate sales in 1961. She continued in this field, eventually becoming the owner of her own reality company. In the 1980’s Myldred’s daughter attended Miami University, studying language and joining the Black Student Action Association. Myldred has visited Miami University multiple times during her life and has especially enjoyed visiting the homes of the families who welcomed her and The Campus Interracial Club during her years as a Miami student. In 2005 the Pioneer Award was established to recognize those who have broken new ground and prepared the way for other African American Students. Myldred Boston Howell exemplified these accomplishments through her tenacity and determination to receive fair treatment. She is a role model, showing those who hear her story that no one should accept improper treatment.

result.bio: Miranda Scott graduated from Miami University in 2019 with a B.S. in Finance, returning to her alma mater in 2022 to pursue an M.B.A. She has worked for Capital One since 2019 and is a Principal Associate on the Healthcare Corporate Finance team.
result.name: Miranda Scott

result.bio: Deborah Scott attended Miami University for both her undergraduate and graduate degrees, earning a B.A. in Education in 1970 and an M.Ed. in 1975 before teaching kindergarten and first grade for thirty-nine years. A staple of the Miami community, Scott has served as a member of the Miami University Alumni Board of Directors, the M.I.A.M.I. WOMEN Giving Circle (as an inaugural member), the Black Alumni Coordinating Committee, and a member of the Committee for Cancer Awareness with Miami’s women's basketball team and Luna Cares. She has received a number of awards for her service to the university, including the Jennie Elder Suel Distinguished Woman of Color Award (2016), the John E. Dolibois Award (2020), and the Don Loss Volunteers of the Year (2021-2022) with her husband Ron.

result.body: On April 15, 1970, a group of students occupied the ROTC building named Rowan Hall to protest the Vietnam War. In this oral history, Donna Ginn and a group of alumni who were present on campus or in the ROTC building sit down and talk about their experiences on that day and at Miami University.
